title: Venue
text:
History of the venue.
The story begins in 1932, when the Rockefeller Building was inaugurated thanks to the support of the Rockefeller Foundation. At that time, it housed the National Institute of Physics and Chemistry, a pioneering centre led by scientists such as Blas Cabrera and Enrique Moles. With state‚Äëof‚Äëthe‚Äëart laboratories and strong international connections, it quickly became one of the most advanced research institutes in Europe.
After the creation of the Spanish National Research Council (CSIC) in the 1940s, part of this scientific legacy evolved into the Rocasolano Institute, formally established in 1946 and named after Antonio de Gregorio Rocasolano, a key figure in the development of physical chemistry in Spain. Since then, the institute has been home to leading research in spectroscopy, molecular physics, structural chemistry, and biophysical sciences.
Today, the Blas Cabrera Istitute continues to combine tradition and innovation, hosting cutting‚Äëedge research while preserving the spirit of scientific curiosity that defined its origins. Its historic Assembly Hall‚Äîwhere the Iberian Prion Meeting 2026 will be held‚Äîhas witnessed decades of lectures, discoveries, and scientific gatherings.
Celebrating the meeting here connects our community with a unique scientific heritage and offers an inspiring setting to discuss the latest advances in prion biology.

title: Venue
section: How to get there. Travel Information
text:
How to get there. Travel Information
Nearest airport
Adolfo Su√°rez Madrid‚ÄìBarajas Airport (MAD) is the closest international airport, located approximately 12‚Äì15 km from Serrano 119. It offers extensive connections to Europe and major intercontinental hubs. Typical travel time to the venue ranges from 20 to 30 minutes depending on traffic and transport mode.
PUBLIC TRANSPORT OPTIONS
Serrano 119 is well connected to Madrid‚Äôs public transport network:
Metro
Line 6 ‚Äì Rep√∫blica Argentina (approx. 5‚Äì7 minutes on foot) Direct connection from Nuevos Ministerios (one stop).
Line 9 ‚Äì Concha Espina (approx. 10 minutes on foot)
Line 10 ‚Äì Gregorio Mara√±√≥n (approx. 12 minutes on foot)
Bus lines (EMT Madrid)
Several lines stop directly along Calle Serrano, within 1‚Äì3 minutes of the venue: 5, 14, 27, 43, 120, 147, 150
Train (Cercan√≠as Renfe)
The nearest station is Nuevos Ministerios (C1, C2, C3, C4, C7, C8, C10), about 15 minutes on foot or a short metro/bus ride. This station also connects directly with the airport (Line C1).
Taxi and ride‚Äëhailing services
Madrid offers reliable and widely available transport services:
Official taxis
A typical ride from the airport to Serrano 119 takes 20‚Äì25 minutes. The airport has a fixed fare to the city center.
Ride‚Äëhailing apps
Uber, Cabify, and Bolt operate throughout Madrid. Pick‚Äëup and drop‚Äëoff at Serrano 119 are straightforward due to wide sidewalks and clear access points.
Recommended routes
From the airport (MAD): Taxi / Ride‚Äëhailing: fastest and most direct option (20‚Äì25 min).
Metro (around 40 min):
Line 8 ‚Üí Nuevos Ministerios
Transfer to Line 6 ‚Üí Rep√∫blica Argentina (1 stop)
Short walk to Serrano 119
Train (Cercan√≠as; around 40 min):
Line C1 ‚Üí Nuevos Ministerios
Metro Line 6 ‚Üí Rep√∫blica Argentina (or a walk from Nuevos Ministerios)
From Atocha train station:
Metro (around 30 min):
Line 1 ‚Üí Cuatro Caminos
Line 6 ‚Üí Rep√∫blica Argentina
Bus, three different bus lines available (around 30 minutes depending on traffic):

Line 14 to Serrano ‚Äì Juan Bravo.
Line 19 to Serrano ‚Äì Rub√©n Dar√≠o (recommended).
Line 27 to Castellana ‚Äì Rub√©n Dar√≠o.

title: Venue
text:
Visiting Madrid
Madrid, the vibrant capital of Spain, offers a rich blend of history, culture, and modernity. Visitors can explore world-renowned museums like the Prado and Reina Sof√≠a, stroll through the elegant Retiro Park, and admire architectural gems such as the Royal Palace and Puerta de Alcal√°. The city‚Äôs dynamic neighborhoods, lively plazas, and culinary scene make it a top European destination. Madrid‚Äôs unique energy and deep historical roots captivate travelers from around the world.

title: Venue
text:
Places not to be missed
Here are some of the places not to be missed in Madrid, each offering a unique glimpse into the city‚Äôs rich history, culture, and charm:

The Prado Museum ‚Äì One of the world‚Äôs greatest art galleries, home to masterpieces by Vel√°zquez, Goya, and El Bosco.
Reina Sof√≠a Museum - Spain‚Äôs national museum of modern art, featuring Picasso‚Äôs iconic Guernica.
Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum - Completes the ‚ÄúGolden Triangle of Art‚Äù with works from Van Gogh, Monet, and Hopper.
Royal Palace of Madrid ‚Äì A grand architectural marvel and official residence of the Spanish monarchy.
Puerta del Sol ‚Äì The symbolic heart of Madrid and the starting point of Spain‚Äôs radial road system.
Plaza Mayor ‚Äì A historic square surrounded by arcades, perfect for strolling and enjoying traditional tapas.
Retiro Park ‚Äì A lush green oasis with sculptures, fountains, and the stunning Crystal Palace.
Gran V√≠a ‚Äì Madrid‚Äôs vibrant avenue lined with theaters, shops, and iconic buildings.
Temple of Debod ‚Äì An ancient Egyptian temple gifted to Spain, offering sunset views over the city.
Cibeles Palace and Fountain ‚Äì A majestic civic building and one of Madrid‚Äôs most photographed landmarks.
Puerta de Alcal√° ‚Äì A neoclassical triumphal arch and symbol of Madrid‚Äôs imperial past.
Plaza de Espa√±a & Torre de Madrid ‚Äì A spacious plaza with monuments and views of the city‚Äôs skyline.

title: Venue
text:
Beyond Madrid
Madrid‚Äôs privileged location makes it an ideal base for exploring some of Spain‚Äôs most remarkable historic cities. All of them are easily accessible by train‚Äîsome in under 30 minutes‚Äîoffering perfect cultural getaways before or after the congress.

Alcal√° de Henares - A UNESCO World Heritage city known for its historic university and as the birthplace of Miguel de Cervantes. Its academic atmosphere and medieval streets make it a cultural treasure. Distance from Madrid: ~35‚Äì41 km Train time: 29‚Äì39 minutes on Cercan√≠as trains
Segovia - Famous for its spectacular Roman aqueduct, fairy‚Äëtale Alc√°zar, and Gothic cathedral. A compact and unforgettable historic city. Distance from Madrid: ~90‚Äì97 km Train time: 28‚Äì35 minutes on high‚Äëspeed AVE/Avlo trains
Toledo - The ‚ÄúCity of Three Cultures,‚Äù known for its cathedral, medieval streets, and panoramic views over the Tajo River. Distance from Madrid: ~73‚Äì87 km Train time: 33 minutes on AVE trains
Aranjuez - Renowned for its Royal Palace and vast historic gardens, Aranjuez offers a peaceful cultural escape with UNESCO recognition. Distance from Madrid: ~47‚Äì50 km Train time: 45‚Äì55 minutes on Cercan√≠as or regional trains
San Lorenzo de El Escorial - Home to the monumental Royal Monastery of El Escorial, a symbol of Spanish history set in the Sierra de Guadarrama foothills. Distance from Madrid: ~49‚Äì58 km Train time: 55‚Äì65 minutes on regional trains
√Åvila - A walled medieval city famous for its perfectly preserved ramparts, Romanesque churches, and spiritual heritage linked to Saint Teresa. Distance from Madrid: ~109‚Äì117 km Train time: 1h 20‚Äì1h 40 on regional or Media Distancia trains

More information on the Official tourism website (available in several languages):
üåê Official Madrid Tourism Website
We hope you enjoy your visit!

title: Registration
text:
To register for the congress, please access the registration form (to be included soon).
Deadline: April 20th, 2026.
Registration fee: 150 euros.
Registration will include:

Congress bag
Access to all scientific and poster sessions
Conference materials
Lunch
Welcome reception, coffee breaks, and evening social sessions (excluding the Conference Symposium)

Two additional rooms are available after request for potential satellite meetings during both Congress days. If you are interested, please contact inia_iberianprion2026@inia.csic.es
On Friday evening (21 May), following the long‚Äëstanding tradition of the Iberian Prion Meetings, we will host an additional optional symposium. It‚Äôs a great chance to meet new colleagues, reconnect with familiar faces, and open the door to new collaborations‚Äîor strengthen the ones you already have. The atmosphere will be relaxed, friendly, and ideal for meaningful conversations that continue advancing prion science while enjoying the company of the wider research community.
If you would like to join the Conference Symposium (networking on prions), an additional fee of 45 euros applies.
If you have any questions about registration, please contact inia_iberianprion2026@inia.csic.es
Cancellation/refund policy: The right of withdrawal may be exercised within 14 calendar days of registration by sending an e-mail to the Technical Secretary (info@grxworkshop.com). Fees will not be refunded after this period.

Deadline for abstract submission: April 13th

title: Abstract Submission
text:
Guidelines

Abstracts should be written in English.

The abstract body should not exceed the word limit specified in the template.

Please indicate your preferred presentation format (oral or poster) when submitting. If you prefer to give an oral presentation, please indicate whether you would like to be considered for selection as an invited talk. There are many slots available for selected oral presentations, but only a few will be chosen as invited talks, which include reimbursement of the registration fee.

title: Iberian Prion Meeting 2026
text:
Madrid, Spain ‚Äî 2026
Welcome to the 14th Iberian Prion Congress in Madrid!
The Iberian Prion Congress has long been a multidisciplinary meeting bringing together experts to explore the shared mechanisms of prion diseases and other protein misfolding disorders.
We are honored to host the 14th Iberian Prion Congress in Madrid, a European capital with a rich political and scientific heritage. The meeting will take place in a historic and influential biomedical institution, uniting leading scientists, clinicians, veterinarians, and specialists from across the Iberian Peninsula and beyond to exchange knowledge and strengthen collaborations. In addition, the active involvement of patient associations will provide an essential perspective, reinforcing the social relevance and human impact of our collective efforts.
As in previous editions, we are committed to fostering the participation of young scientists, whose innovative ideas and fresh perspectives drive progress in prion research. Dedicated sessions and interactive discussions will offer them opportunities for presentation, mentorship, and scientific exchange.
Inspired by Madrid‚Äôs vibrant intellectual atmosphere and the collaborative spirit of this congress, we aim to explore new frontiers and work toward solutions to the challenges posed by prion diseases. We extend our sincere gratitude to all participants, speakers, sponsors, and volunteers for their essential contributions.
We look forward to welcoming you to Madrid and joining forces to build new partnerships that will help pave the way toward conquering prion diseases and bringing hope to those affected.
The Organizing Committee
